Dialogue: It's all right, it is stupid. Real stupid. He did it on a bet. He bet someone twenty bucks that he could do it. He made it all the way out there, too. He went through the ice on his way back.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I think my dad was like Jacey is. Some guys are just dare-devils. I bet Jacey once that he couldn't do a back-flip off the garage roof into a big pile of leaves. And he did it.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: One time Eleanor and I snuck out and walked around the yard naked.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Yeah. It was sort of a dare, too. She dared me, I dared her, so we both did it.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: You walked around the yard or did you like run from tree to tree?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: We just walked around the yard.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Yeah. Back yard nudity is hypocritical. It's insincere. People should do and say exactly what they feel or think and not try to hide things.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: Don't tell... don't tell anyone what we're doing... don't tell anyone... no one can know, Jacey... no one...

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Don't forget to water my tomatoes!

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: How long is your mom gone?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Two weeks. She goes up every summer to see this friend she went to college with.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Yeah. She's going to stewardess school.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: What do they teach you at stewardess school?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I don't know.    How to wiggle your bottom.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Maybe you should go there instead of Bryn Mawr?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: It was an accident. Don't be crabby.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I just thought maybe you were tired of just kissing?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I'm not tired of kissing.    Are you?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I just... you know... would like to see what you look like without any clothes on.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: No, I know what I look like without any clothes on -- I look naked.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: No. You can kiss me.      I like lips.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I like your lips, block-head. I like being here like this. But I'm not taking my clothes off, 'cause if we do that, you know what we'll do. And I'm too... I don't want to be like my sisters. Not if I can help it.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: My brother. He just went upstairs with your sister.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Hell, I didn't know. What does this got to do with us?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: My God... what is she doing?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Why is it okay for you to sneak around with me, but it's not all right for Alice to sneak around with Jacey?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Because I'm not Alice! And you're not Jacey! Alice is... is like my mom, they both get hurt so easy, they're like turtles without shells.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: You don't know my father. You don't know how he is about Jacey. He blames him for everything that happened with Eleanor.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Eleanor fooled around with lots of guys, it's not Jacey's fault your dad kicked her out.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Oh, Jesus! He didn't kick her out, he put her in a nut house! He shipped her off to this clinic in Wisconsin.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: But... I thought you said she's in Chicago?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: She is now.     They let her out a month ago.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: It's the truth, you know it is.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: No, no, it's all just... screwing.

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: I spend all day, every day, just waiting and waiting to be with you, waiting to forget everything, you make me forget... but then when I get dressed and I come home, you... just... leak out of me. Leak away. I go into the bathroom and I wash you off of me and I remember everything.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You can talk inside.     It's late.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I've been thinking -- maybe we shouldn't see each other right now.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Well... if my father... I don't really care what would happen to me if he found out I was seeing you, but I have to take care of Alice and my mother and Eleanor, and... well, it would be hard for me to do that if I were in the doghouse, too. You know?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Christ, why do you have to take care of them?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: How long is she likely to stay?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I don't know, but I wouldn't hold up dinner.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Don't sit on the swing -- Doug just painted it.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: I know.  I had to bring her here today. She couldn't see me tonight and there was nowhere else we could go.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I can appreciate that, Jacey, but...

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: I love her, Mother. I'm going to marry her.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Do her parents know about this?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: I don't give a damn about them.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Does Alice feel the same as you do?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Has she agreed to marry you?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: She will. She needs time. She's frightened. It's not easy for her.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: How does hiding it from her family make it any easier?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Alice is a grown woman, she's a mother with a child of her own; if she really loves you then she should...

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: All that matters is that I get her away from them before they find out.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I can't be a party to that, Jacey.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: I don't need your help.   I'm not asking for it.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You'll have to find somewhere else to take Alice -- I can't have you bringing her here again. I'm sorry.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Alice? Did you hear me? Susan cut her finger on the piano pedal.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Alice took some pills, some of my mother's pills...

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: She's all right, we took her to the hospital...

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: No. That's why she sent me, she doesn't want you to come, she was afraid you would if you heard from someone else. She's all right.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: But I have to see her.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Dammit, no! I'm warning you, just wait! I'll let you know just as soon as she can see you. Please, don't make things worse. Don't.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Leave me alone, just leave me alone.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: At the boathouse -- at the lake.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I had to... for Alice's sake.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I have plans for my daughters, Mr. Holt, and they don't include you. I know you. I know you better than you know me. I know all there is to know about screwing your way into a wealthy family. I'll never let you screw your way into mine.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: Who do you think you are?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Come with me. Please, Alice, just come with me now, right now.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Now, get out of here, you runt stud. And keep your poor-boy dick out of my daughters.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Why spend all night and half the day tomorrow waiting in Chicago for the Philadelphia bus? Why not just wait and take the morning bus to Chicago?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Because... the sooner I get out of this fucking town the better.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Dammit... why can't he just leave them alone?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: The Abbotts. I don't know why... why couldn't he just forget 'em? Just pretend they didn't even exist?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: If the Abbotts didn't exist, Jacey would've had to invent them, one way or another. There are no ends of Abbotts in the world, if that's what you need.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: What do you mean, how do you know?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I was just a wreck when Charlie died.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: After Charlie died Lloyd Abbott started dropping by on his way home from work. He felt so bad about that bet Charlie made with him at the lake. That foolish, idiotic bet. Poor Lloyd -- I felt sorry for him. He'd have a cup of coffee with Mother and me. If a doorknob had come off he'd fix it. He'd carry the garbage cans to the curb. Someone dies, people try to be helpful. But he was by here so often that people started to talk. It was fairly obvious that he wanted something more from me than just a cup of coffee. I suggested that he didn't need to stop by here so often, but... then one afternoon I was at Woolworth's, having lunch at the counter. All of sudden Joan Abbott was standing there -- screaming and yelling at me to stop sleeping with her husband, with Lloyd. I was speechless. She was gone before I could find my tongue.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I went to see Joan, I tried to talk to her, to put her mind at ease, but...

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Dammit, why didn't Lloyd tell her that nothing had happened?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm sure he did, but men always say that, darling. Besides, Lloyd was always having affairs. He's that type of man.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Ahhh, Jesus... but why? Why did everyone in town believe Joan Abbott?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Because she's Joan Abbott. If you cross Joan you don't get invited to her parties -- and the Abbotts have the best parties in town. The only parties.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I hate this town. I hate the Abbotts.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Doug, I shouldn't have told you.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: No, I've never heard anyone talk about it. Not to me.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Yeah. But he thinks it really happened.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Airplanes, bridges, skyscrapers, bras, all utilize the same fundamentals of structural design...

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: A stable foundation that resists compression...

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: And cantilevered elements to provide support.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: I'm engaged in conversation with you.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I come down to use the library sometimes or go shopping.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Very... Bryn.    I got to catch the bus back.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Just have to drop off these set designs -- you want to go get something to eat?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Why not?   It's been a long time.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I can't.   I have to go to this party.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Just a party I got roped into going. Maybe some other time, okay? I mean it, really.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Just call -- I'm at Reed Hall.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Damn, you're drunk. Awww, man... I better get you out of here before the Puritans tar-and-feather you. Can you walk?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Listen to me -- go out the front door, turn right, go around to the side of the building and wait for me by the fire escape. Okay? Just wait.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Come on -- up we go.   Pam?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Hold on, we got to get your pants too. Can you stand up.  No, you can't stand up. All right.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Nope, nope, let's keep the panties on, okay? Pam? Can you hold on to your underpants?  I'll hold on to your underpants.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Goddammit. Well, I know you might find this hard to believe, but I don't sleep with drunks.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Doug! Open the window!     Come on, I'm freezing. Doug...!

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: If you feel like you're gonna puke use the wastebasket there.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I am so sorry. I was embarrassed. I didn't know where I was when I woke up. I felt like I was dying, so, I just... I was going to call you.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I don't know... I was blotto. I mean, I was so happy to see you. Then I just got sad. I got sad. And stupid. It happens, you know?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: You want to hear something stupid?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: When I was cleaning you up, wiping the puke off your face, I suddenly realized how much I miss you -- how much I love you. How's that for stupid?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I love you.   But it's too late.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: No, no, it's not too late. It's perfect timing. We're on our own now. No Jacey and Eleanor or Jacey and Alice. That's what stinks about being the youngest, we have to sweep up after everybody else. But now it's just us. It's our turn.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: How can you be in love with me?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: How can you be in love with me?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: 'Cause I've always have been. You... block-head.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I want to show you something.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: The senior acting class does scenes from different plays, they invite everybody, it's a real big deal. So, there's this competition among all the theater design students to do the sets. And -- anyway -- I'm the one whose design got picked.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: What scene is it for?     What play?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Umm... Romeo and Juliet. It's something different, I think that's why they picked it. Everybody else was doing castles and stuff. Rooftop Romeo and Juliet by Douglas L. Holt.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: It's like building models when I was a kid. It's fun. It's... make-believe.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: You know, they tore that old farmhouse down?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: They always tear down the wrong stuff.

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: Oh, Jesus, I missed you -- so much.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Well, what? You worried what your old man would think?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: He doesn't care what I do, as long as I don't do it in Haley.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Why not? I mean... okay. We don't have to go so fast. Shit, I'm sorry. I blew it again, huh?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: I'm on probation. They pulled a bed-check the night I was here. I have to be back in the dorm by ten. Gotta go.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: What about tomorrow? I could come up in the afternoon and...

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: No! It's just too late. It's all messed up. I can't seem to make things all right. The more I try the worse everything gets. I'm sorry.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: How did you know I was here?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: I told you not to come by on Sundays.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Dammit, why didn't you call first?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Well, I didn't expect to see you again. You want to fuck? I mean, that's why you came over, right?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: I did.  I ran into her a few weeks ago at a party. She was drinking and I... it was easy. She felt guilty about telling her father about Alice and me. Actually, I made her feel guilty, I made her feel like she had betrayed Alice.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: She didn't betray Alice! She was just trying to get rid of you so Alice wouldn't try to kill herself again. Jesus Christ, you shit- head, Alice couldn't marry you!

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: I know.    I mean, I do now.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Then what the hell did Pam ever do to deserve your revenge?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Just your way of evening the score with Lloyd Abbott, right?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I don't know   you! I don't know who the fuck   you are! You fuck everything.    You fuck everything up! Why did    you have to fuck Pam, too?!

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Pamela Abbott, please.     Tell her Doug is here.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I mean... thanks. Thanks anyway. I know her home address.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I couldn't find Eleanor's name in the Chicago phone book.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Well, do you know Eleanor's address?

Speaker: alice
Dialogue: No. I don't know her address, I don't know her phone number. You'd have to ask my father for it. All right?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I do wish Jacey had come home for Christmas. Maybe that's what's wrong with me.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I guess that free-lance drafting job was too good for him to turn down.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I don't think that's why he didn't come home. I wrote him a letter, you know. About Lloyd and me. Has he mentioned it to you?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: When did you start drinking beer?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Oh... I bought those for you. I had them in the basement; I kept forgetting to bring them up.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Good heavens, I know you drink beer.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I bought those for you, honey.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: It's not good to drink alone, Mom.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Come on.   Sit down.   Have a beer.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Charlie was always trying to get me to drink beer.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Why do you always call him Charlie?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Why don't you ever say 'your father'?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Sometimes I do, don't I? I don't know. When I think of him, I think of 'Charlie.'

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Did you ever... meet anybody else?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Well, everyone always thinks things are more possible than they are. I mean, single men don't stay in Haley if they have any starch. The only eligible man around was Drew Carter, but he smells like his dog.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I wish I'd remembered the beers sooner. It's nice to see you smiling.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Don't be.   Everyone has sad times.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'll tell you a secret. I did have a friend. A man in Chicago. I used to see him when I went up to Chicago to visit Bea during summer vacations.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: 'Used to see him' -- you don't see him anymore?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: He was a wonderful man. A little boring, but really, very wonderful.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: How long did this go on?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: About eight years or so, it was when you boys were still at home.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: That's a long time. Did you ever think about marrying him?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: He proposed.   But, well, obviously, I said no.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Because I'm in love with... your father. With my memory of him. He was the one for me. Oh, I don't know... there's different kinds of love, darling. Some people you love no matter what. Other people you love if the situation is right. To me the best kind of love is the 'no matter what' kind.  Well, I am a cheap drunk, aren't I?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Too much noise, please. Let's finish up. Keep the glue on the paper. Sam, Lillian, Jack -- in your seats, please...

Speaker: eleanor
Dialogue: How's your chin?  Remember... the pencil?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Yeah.    I have a little scar.

Speaker: eleanor
Dialogue: You going home? Back to Hole-in- the-Ground, Illinois.

Speaker: eleanor
Dialogue: Oh God. Oh no. Oh, Doug, I'm sorry.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: She had cancer. I just saw her Christmas. She was tired, but I thought she just had the flu or something. She didn't tell us. The hospital told Jacey when they called him.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: He had to stay to take his state board exams. He's coming back the day after tomorrow.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: If he passes his exams.   He will.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: You know, I tried to find your phone number a couple of months ago.

Speaker: eleanor
Dialogue: It's in my roommate's name, I've got to fix that.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I was wondering if you knew where Pam was?

Speaker: eleanor
Dialogue: I know.   My father called me.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Tell her... just tell her that.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Why?   Why didn't she tell us?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Do you want this picture of Grandma?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I'm starving. You want to go get something to eat?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: You don't have to stick around.     I can handle things here.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I hate Penn.   Always have.   You were right.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I should live my own life. Stop being your shadow. I'm not like you, Jacey -- I don't want to be like you.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: You going to stay here?   In Haley?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: No. I was thinking New York. If I'm going to really learn how to design sets, that's the place to do it.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I know you are.  Did you have to get stitches?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Found this in one of the boxes in the basement.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: A letter of agreement between Lloyd Abbott and Dad. Dad sold him the file drawer patent -- not Mom.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Jesus Christ... he sold the patent for a used car?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Used cars were the only kind of cars around. The war was on -- everything was mobilized. They stopped making new cars, they were making tanks and bombers in Detroit. And even Midwest Steel wasn't making desks, they were making ammo boxes and mortar shells.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: How did you get to be such an expert on World War Two?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: U.S. History -- high school. I should be an expert, I had to take the damn class twice. I guess Dad needed a car and he figured who- the-hell needed a full-suspension file drawer?

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: He parked it at the bottom of the lake.

Speaker: jacey
Dialogue: Do me a favor. Don't stand here and wave good-bye... it makes me think of Mom.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I want to talk to you.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Then don't.  I'm sorry about your mother.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: You didn't know your mother at all if you think someone like me would've ever stood a chance with someone like her. That just goes to show you how stupid this town is -- that they'd believe she slept with me. That'd make Charlie laugh. Your old man was my best friend. He used to call me 'Egg-head' -- hell, everybody did. And back then everybody knew that Egg-head Abbott didn't stand a snowball's chance in hell with Helen Riley. Of course, that was all before I became Lloyd Abbott -- Mr. Abbott. That was back when I still had chicken shit on my shoes and twelve cents in my pocket. Charlie Holt was the only one good enough for Helen. I used to spy on 'em -- yup, I did.

Speaker: joan
Dialogue: It's time for Susie's birthday cake.

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: Goddammit, Joan, go way! Get the hell out of here! Leave me alone!

Speaker: lloyd
Dialogue: I wanted sons -- isn't that funny? I wanted sons and I got three daughters. I wanted a woman I could talk to and I got a woman whose ears are stuffed full of money and Percodan. But I got the chicken shit off my shoes.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: I want to find Pam -- and you're going to tell me where she is.

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: You always loved me no matter what I did, right?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Maybe that's how I love you -- no matter what. That's the best kind of love, you know?

Speaker: pamela
Dialogue: But... oh, Jesus... how do we start all over again?

Speaker: doug
Dialogue: Starting over.     So, what are you doing tonight?     You want to go out?
